in the direction of the arrows near "FCM". To identify this rotation as one according to the right hand rule we note: The axis of rotation is oriented by the displayed vector, call it \Vect{z}. Upon aligning the thumb of your right hand with \Vect{z}, your curled fingers point in the direction of the rotation.
The relationship between a "rotation according to the right hand rule" and the "right hand orientation" is obtained as follows.

li.para: Choose any nonzero vector \Vect{x} perpendicular to \Vect{z}.
Let \Vect{y} be the result of rotating \Vect{y} through the angle of \pi/2 according to the right hand rule.
Then the triple (\Vect{x},\Vect{y},\Vect{z}) represents the right hand orientation of \RNr[3].
